text: Almost opaque dark brown/deep red color with a copper hue. Slightly creamy and bubbly light brown 2-3 finger head, lasting around 5 minutes, not much legs, average lace, light swirl effect. Flavors of liquorice, cherries, dark berries, molasses, dark grains, coffee, chocolate, oak, toffee, herbal spices. Thick fruity and malty sweetness, with balanced bitterness. Soft creamy, and slick, medium body with crispy carbonation. Medium to strong strength finish, slightly leathery and dry, moderately spicy, light vinous dark ester fruits, herbal and bready, soft woody whiskey feel that lingers for a while. Not the bold type of scotch ale, but well intensified, nor overly spicy. Good freshness while highly warming. Very good taste, quickly dominated by a nice barrel feel. Overall excellent quality craft.

Bouteille. Liquide filtré et profondément ambré aux reflets rouges. Tête cossue formée de grosses bulles. La tête ne saccroche toutefois pas au verre mais peu importe. Nez bien léger où les épices dominent sur trame boisée. Présence fort appréciable des malts qui confère une belle structure à la bière. Un beau petit côté butter Scotch également mais jamais écoeurant ni sucré. Cest fou la buvabilité de cette bière! Les gorgées senlignent et jamais au grand jamais je ne sens lalcool. Parfaitement légère en bouche, facile à boire, bien effervescente et maltée. Les saveurs sont somme toutes peu complexes et le mouthfeel léger comme une plume. Difficile à croire que je bois une Scotch Ale. Bravo Élise pour cette bière qui repousse les limites du style.

341ml bottle, best before 2017-06-12. Pour dark brown with some reddish note. Minimal non lasting big bubble foam. Aroma of dark malt, wood, butterscotch caramel. Taste is first from ethanol, second from spirits and third from malt. Finish is a balance of alcohol and bitterness.

Gifted by mon frere: pours brown with a small head. Aroma is caramel, malts, bananas, ambiguous fruitiness. Taste is somewhat sweet and quite malty. Has some characteristics you would find in a Belgian ale, like the fruitiness and even something in the yeastiness. Body has not too heavy but still had oomph. A pleasant beer to drink.

Bière brunâtre, aux reflets plutôt noirs, avec une fine ligne de carbonatation et un teint opaque. Au nez, cassonade, malt torréfié et caramel annoncent une bière plutôt sucré. En bouche, la bière est intéressante et sort du lot pour une scotch ale. Le liquide est, certes, sucré comme une scotch ale, mais laisse également des impressions de fumée et damertume un peu terreuse, ce qui fait plutôt différent des scotch ales plus classiques. La bière a également une bonne effervescence en bouche. Au final cest bien fait mais sans plus.

Bouteille de 9 mois. 
Apparence : Brune foncée, reflets rouges, carbonatation moyenne tout comme la rapidité, beau col moka, peu de dentelle. 
Nez : Sucre grillé, fruits rouges (canneberges, cerises?), boisé, côté épicé. 
Goût : Caramel (un peu fade?), fruits rouges mûrs, boisé, assez sucrée, touche damertume en finale avec le sucre résiduel. 
Sensation : Effervescence moyenne, épicée sur la langue, corps moyen, finale de longueur moyenne. 
Bref : Bonne bière présentant un équilibre entre le malt (caramel sucré), le bois, lamertume et les fruits. Il manque par contre de profondeur à mon goût. Ça se boit bien, mais il ny a rien pour faire ressortir cette offrande du lot. Il ma semblé noté lalcool davantage dans certains brassins précédents. Bien équilibrée.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2015 Bouteille expirant le 22/01/17, bue après plus de 9 mois. Robe brune orangée très trouble sans col de mousse. Dentelle pratiquement inexistante. Arômes de café, caramel brûlé, alcool, mélasse et banane noir. Plus ou moins complexe, peut-être un peu trop de notes brûlées. En bouche, cest surtout orienté vers le caramel brûlé et la mélasse. Suivent des saveurs de café cappuccino, chocolat noir à lorange et citron. Par contre on retrouve un meilleur équilibre quau nez mais manque encore de complexité. Carbonatation un peu trop élevé. Reste une très bonne scotch ale dans l?ensemble.
A bit more subtle compared to many Scotch ales Ive had in the past. The salty taste from the sea water is a welcome paring with the caramel aspect this style often has.

I like this much more than the Corne de Glace. Nice clear pour with a rich dark brown color. Average, creamy, off white head that diminishes fairly quickly.Fair lacing. Malty aroma of molasses and caramel with hints of allspice and vanilla. I did not pick up on the ripe berries until later in the glass. Light sweet taste initially with a moderate sweet spicy finish. The 9% ABV is well hidden and the texture is far from heavy. For a Scotch Ale, I like it! Cheers!

Pours a dark ruby with a medium beige head that fades into a small rim and doesnt leave much lacing. Nose is of caramel, raisins and light some. A scotch ale for sure. Taste is moderately sweet, offers fruits and peat along with some algae (weird I know, but I really got it). Licorice and pepper. Body is medium and carbonation high, too high for a scotch ale. Finish is a little hot but what do you expect from a 9% scotch ale? Overall a good one although the carbonation is killing it a little for me.

belle scotch ale , belle mousse qui colle un tout petit peu sur le verre. goût de vanille,boisé, un peut salé , caramel , pain grillé , noisette subtile, belle chaleur en gorge , alcool très bien caché . une belle rondeur. une final très sucré (un peut trop?) mais en bout de ligne très bonne bière , a boire lhiver surtout selon moi. cheer

341ml bottle from a gift. @home 24-08-2014.
BBD: 08/11/2015.
Pours very dark with some tan head. Short head retention, some lacing. Roasty, smoky, caramel, liquor and wood aromas. Medium body, soft carbonation, oily texture. Taste follows the nose, warming mouthfell, smooth, balanced, some sweet notes. Very enjoyable.

Dabord je pensais quelle était noire opaque, mais avec plus de lumière, jai vue le beau reflet couleur rubis. Bière puissante aux arômes de caramel, bois et dester de fruit mûres foncés qui donne un coté piquant. Elle est très sucré et meilleur lorsque réchauffé. Elle me fait demandé cest quoi la différence entre une Scotch Ale et un Vin dorge? Excellent, rien à dire.

I met these guys at the PEI BeerFest and they were super friendly. Also and importantly, their beer kicked ass. All of the beers and the whole ass. A pretty dark brown rust pours out with a light tan head. Offers up some dark fruits, raisins, vanilla and allspice, woodiness and wet straw. A beautiful, complex Scotch Ale that I wish would be available in PEI along with everything they make. Light on the carbonation and an easy drinking mouthfeel add to the enjoyment. I find thick Scotch Ales difficult to palate. If anyone from this brewery is reading this PLEASE GET YOUR BEERS ON PEI!
La Couleur est brune-rougâtre. Avec un Arôme et saveur de mélasse, dalcool et de fruits murs. Son corps est moyen. Les saveurs restent en bouche. cette bière est trés bonne !

Bouteille de 341 ml. Embouteillée en septembre 2009, dégustée le 31 janvier 2010 (Thistle). Bière brune bourgogne limpide. Mousse très très peu, col beige très mince et éphémère. Très peu effervescente. Odeur de bois, doranges brûlées (Cointreau), de cognac, de sucre brûlé. Saveur de bois brûlé, de peat moss, de pomme verte, de cerises marasquin. Alcool ne ressort pas trop. Goût/saveur un peu trop éparpillé genre salade de fruits, all over thé place. Très bonne mais compte tenu de la réputation et du prix de cette bière je mattendais à mieux.

Brune aux reflets rougeâtres. Nez: caramel. Fruit rouge. Vanille. Fumée. Biscuit au gingembre. Bouche: sucré. Malté/caramel. Toffee. Vanille. Fraise/framboise. Boisé. Légèrement fumée. Épice. Un peu herbacé. Très bien.
Couleur brune-rougâtre. Très peu de moussante. Arôme et saveur de mélasse, de grains grillés, dalcool et de fruits murs. Corps est moyen. Les saveur reste modérément en bouche. Bonne !!

Bière de couleur brune avec peu de mousse. Nez de caramel et dépices. En bouche cest un complexe et subtil mélange dépices comme la cannelle et le clou de giroffle, caramel, chocolat, café, sel, grains grillés, quelques fruits rouges. Mis a part toute cette complexité jai trouvé que cette bière avait un gout plutôt moyen, pas du tout impressionné mais pas mauvaise!

Bottle. Pours caramel brown with a small beige head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, dried fruit and light spices. Flavor was quite sweet with caramel, oak, dried dark fruit, subtle smoke and some winter spices. Medium bodied light carbonation.

A little syrupy a little nutty a little pruney. Chalky texture reminds me much more of an old ale than a scotch. Prune and fruity aroma. Muddy brown color. Finish is a little touch of soy sauce. Bit of a slow sipping beer.

11.5 oz bottle courtesy of Chris, served in a snifter. Pours clear reddish brown with a small tan head that fades to a thin remnant and leaves a small amount of fine lace. The nose has notes of caramel, toffee, dried fruit, subtle spices and perhaps some oak. The flavour is moderately sweet up front with caramel and perhaps honey paired with subtle hops. The hops increase through the middle and join with subtle spices to form a long, lingering finish. On the palate it is light-medium in body with a milky texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a nice scotch ale, but one that seems light for the style. 2013-12-12

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2014 Bière brune foncé aux reflets rubis, plutôt limpide, bonne effervescence, et surmontée dun col brunâtre dense et mousseux, et bien persistant. Arôme principal de banane très mûre et sucrée accompagné deffluves de pain grillé et de caramel, avec un alcool évident et quelques notes boisées. On décèle également des odeurs de fruits foncés séchés (raisin sec, datte, pruneau). Nez intéressant mais un peu surprenant pour le style (banane?), très intense, complexité adéquate. En bouche, le breuvage est peu pétillant, plutôt mousseux, et il présente une belle onctuosité au palais, belle rondeur, cest moelleux et velouté. Au goût, domination de lalcool et du boisé, avec du pain grillé, grains rôtis et une certaine saveur de caramel qui me semble plutôt timide pour le style. On retrouve également en bouche les fruits très mûrs voire confits (raisin, prune/pruneau, banane). Un certain houblon floral semble se pointer en fin de bouche en route vers une finale à lamertume de faible à modérée. Bonne intensité, complexité moyenne. Il sagit dune bien bonne bière qui mérite bien son excellente réputation, mais je préfère personnellement les scotch ales davantage axé sur les sucres et moins sur lalcool et le boisé. /// Cette bière vieillit très bien dit-on, et jai eu lopportunité de déguster en novembre 2014 une Corne de Brume embouteillée en septembre 2010 (vieillie plus de 4 ans donc!). Liquide beaucoup plus trouble, remplie de particules en fait. Beaucoup doxydation (carton, pâte à pain), alcool toujours dominant, boisé et impression rôti/grillé atténués, sucres rehaussés (caramel/cassonade), houblon et amertume presque totalement disparus, très très douce en général, intégration parfaite des différentes saveurs. Résultat intéressant, mais rien pour monter sa note

12 oz. bottle shared by Rastacouere at RBSG 2010 from notes. Pours a reddish brown color with a medium sized thick beige head. The aroma was caramel/toffee malts, a toasted roasted malt character, some fig and raisin with some light floral stuff creeping in. The flavor is more malt forward as well; caramel/toffee, toasted bread, fruity character with some mild earthy notes at the finish. Well worth trying.

Bière brune foncée et opaque aux reflets rougeâtres. Le col mousseux est mince; il fait le tour du verre comme un halo paisible. Au nez, on sent un peu de cannelle piquante (dans le style des bonbons en forme de poisson rouge), du caramel, de la gomme baloune, de lanis... bref, cest épicé et festif. En bouche, le caramel se révèle comme le leader des troupes; les épices obéissent et se dévoilent en finale. La bière est enveloppante et savoureuse  beaucoup de texture et de surprises qui samoncellent alors que la concoction se réchauffe. Le produit est TRÈS cher, mais il offre tout de même des standards de qualité à la hauteur de son prix. Toutefois, je nen achèterais pas sur une base régulière; quand on peut avoir 500ml de MacKroken pour à peu près le même prix, il faut savoir faire des choix.
Excellente, un goût qui reste en bouche très onctueux. A essayer absolument. Une incontournable

This $7 beer doesnt quite have a $7 taste. Pours dark brown with good foam (mocha colour) and lacing. Sharp oaky taste in here, but light for a scotch ale. Im not even sure whether this is a dark Belgian or a mild scotch ale. Somewhere in between. Caramelized malt. Definitely some woodiness and astringency in finish. Bottle.

A decent beer from Quebec that packs a powerful punch with that 8.7% ABV. It pours reddish brown and the aroma is somewhat sweet with caramel and brown sugar. The flavour is malty sweet with a hidden bitter finish. Alcohol predominates.

Draft at Le St-Bock 1/20/2013 with Ricky, Andy, PJ on Montreal Broquest 2013. Black pour and creamy head. Milky palate. Dark/roasty taste with notes of sugar. Not as boozey as I was hoping for, but pretty decent anyway.

Bouteille 500ml. De couleur cuivrée-brune et claire. Nez de mélasse, de caramel toffee aux notes terreuses, fruité (raisins, notes de cerises et de dates), petites notes de chocolat noir et de sucre brun avec des effluves dalcool liquoreux. Assez ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen-doux et une texture crémeuse et légèrement liquoreuse. Goût fruité légèrement vineux et aux faibles notes sûres (raisins vineux, notes de dates et traces de cerises) avec un léger goût de vanille et de fumée de bois lors de lentrée en bouche suivi dun goût malté sucré rappelant le caramel toffee légèrement rôti et terreux avec des notes de sucre brun ainsi quun goût de mélasse sucrée et en finale, lon retrouve une légère chaleur dalcool liquoreux avec des petites notes amères de rôti et de chocolat ainsi quun léger goût de noix grillées. Post-goût légèrement amer dalcool et de rôti un léger goût fruité (moût de raisins et cerises) ainsi que des traces de houblon herbeux, de noix et de chocolat.
Bouteille de 341ml, robe brune foncée, arôme de sucre résiduel, goût de caramel torréfié et de pain rôtie.

Sweet malty date and roasted grain aroma with a molasses undertone. Murky brown, thin head. Dates are very dominant and there is a hint of tartness that may not belong .  Watery. Thankfully, it isnt as sweet as I feared. More malty than fruity on the palate. Woody and tart, but not quite like an oud bruin. This is not a favorite style for me, but this isnt a good example. Bottled on date of 2/1/10. Overaged, perhaps.

341mL bottle, pours a deep dark mahogany with a small tan head. Aroma is very feint, revealing notes of smoky sweet whiskey malts (though mostly sweet and not very smoky), and some subdued dark dried fruits. Flavour is similar and surprisingly subdued for such a big beer, with notes of sweet scotch malts, dark dried fruits, and maybe some oxidized notes. Very mellow and restrained - too much so. Not seeing what the big deal here is. Just OK.

Bottle (341 ml). Unclear brown with a low fully lasting beige head and some lacing. Aroma of caramel, smokey malt and peat. Taste is about the same but caramel and peat are stronger than expected are theres hints of dark fruits. Slight bitterness. Good balance. Nice right on style Scotch Ale though more peated than most of the other Scotch Ale that Ive tried so far.

Bottle.  Pours deep dark brown.  Smoky aroma, with some evergreen.  Sweet up front, moving into dry, smoky, piney, flavours, with some grape and maybe even some licorice.  Slight sourness to it as well?  Dry somewhat bitter finish.  Interesting, and good.

November 2011 bottle shared by kevinsenn. Aroma is sweet caramel with a hint of smoky peat. Pours deep ruby almost black, with just a lacy trace of head. Flavour is rich and warm... Sweet toffee without much bitterness.  A bit of grape in there too. The oak is present in there. Its different from other scotch ales. Body is fairly full and smooth. Quite pleasant on the tongue. Good stuff!

January 2011 bottle via a trade. Pours with a cola/prune brown hued body with a medium sized off-white head that lasts. Aromas are of brown sugar, stewed fruits, black tea, mild spice, oak, nougat/almond paste. Very rich in dark fruit and malt character. Good complexity. Oatmeal. Light leather and a touch of smoke, with mild alcoholic warmth. Tastes are nutty, medium tannic, surprisingly dry, somewhat thin, tea, porridge and brown sugar. Light nutmeg, lots of cereal and toasted malt. A strong raisin and date flavor. Medium bitter, light earthy notes. Feels like a lot of faded hope. Mild oak. Thinner mouthfeel, light marmalade, medium bodied with lighter carbonation.

Bottle at home. 2009 vintage. Thanks TheJester for throwing this across the pond. It pours hazy amber with a creamy beige head. The aroma is heavy fruity with notes of caramel, ripe fruit, light sour berries and biscuits. The flavour is toasted caramel with notes of ripe fruit, light alcohol, light spices and has a great biscuit base. Very good indeed! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from 12 oz. bottle at the Mussel Bar, in Bethesda, MD. 

Opaque near black with almost no head although fairly good lacing. 

Aroma of brown sugar, toffee, tomato sauce?!, oak, peat and molasses. 

Taste of smokey peat, toasted malt, molasses, black pepper and tomato. 

Medium/light body and medium/light carbonation. 

An unusual Scotch Ale--sweet and smokey. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bouteille 341ml. Couleur brun-rouge, peu de mousse. Arôme de mélasse, de grains grillés, dalcool. Au goût, mélasse, fruits murs et un peu de chocolat en fin de bouche. Encore un beau produit de cette micro-brasserie.

355ml bottle - shared by Les Quebecois in Lithuania - thanks!
Hazy-to-cloudy orangy brown. Very full body. Rich soy malts. Sweet, yet hopped to be slightly drying in the finish. A sipper - comfy chair, fireplace, and pipe recommended.
Bottle, pours dark brown, the aroma is nice it has some bourbony and some scotch and the flavour is full of life, the taste is quite nice, really interesting stuff

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2012 Bottle 341ml.
Pours brown with low beige head. Aroma is of caramel, sweetness. Taste is of caramel, malt, sligth bitterness. Creamy feeling. Palate: Medium body. Overall: Not bad, well-balanced. Had it in blind tasting, almost died from beeing oversweetened. Note: 7 Scotch Ale is too much. Glad I had it again tough, as my former rating seems quite innacurate. Still a style I dont completely enjoy. Not very drinkable.

[Former rating] [6/3/6/3/13]
Bottle 341ml.
Pours dark red, with low beige head. Aroma is of home ketshup (sweet), fruits, and wild, sour. Taste is of old yogurt, yeast, kind of reminding Duchesse de Bourgogne, but smoother. Cherries, nuts, wood? Creamy mouthfeel. Not my style.

from le Mondial de la Bière 2011, Strasbourg - cloudy dark brown beer with a little long lasting beige foam; nice lacework; complex and very malty aroma with notes of caramel, hazelnuts and spices, hints of vanilla and plums; full-bodied and very tasty, some sweetness and a decent tart bitterness on top of a fair carbonation; slightly dry and long spicy malty toffeish aftertaste with warming alcohol notes -- an absolute beauty
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is milky sour, caramel, alcohol. Flavour is malt, alcohol, caramel, nuts. Ordinary beer.

341 ml bottle. Fluffy white head, dark orange color. Caramel malts, cinnabon and oak. Pretty sweet, still, balanced by a higher than average saltiness. Low carbonation. 

A decent brew: Yes. Worth 6,99$ ? No.
#1029 Bottle; Nose is leaves, mediumsour malt, weak chloride, wood chip, feel is mediumwatery, carb is medium, taste is sour plum, some wet hops, cooked vegetables,

341 mL bottle courtesy of my 2011 Secret Santa, JulienHuxley. Thanks! Pours a hazy dark red color with a large frothy tan head. Good head retention. Big fruity notes in the aroma including strawberry, citrus, candied citrus and berries. Faint toffee notes. The taste is tart fruits. Berries, strawberry, plum, citrus, caramel. Medium bodied. Some booze. Interesting, but not quite what Im expecting from a Scotch Ale. Looking now at some other ratings of this and Im not getting any of the notes others raters are, so I assume this bottle is off. Sad. At least its still drinkable.

Une découverte.  Arôme de malt enveloppant, de grains fraîchement moulus et présence dune arôme dalcool subtile.  Houblonnée sans exagération, très bien balancée, de loin une des meilleures bière que jai goûté.  Elle sapparente à une belge forte.  Dépasse mes attentes.  Une bière excellente made in Quebec!

Nice deep amber coloured body with a nice fresh ruby and copper tint and a thinnish tan head. Aroma of nuts, smoke, a touch of earthy hops, dirt, alcohol and quite a bit of toffee - nice pungent aroma. Full-bodied; Strong earthy and nutty flavour at first with a great complex backbone and almost a spicey bite with some light oak, a little hay and grassy flavours and finishing with alcohol. Aftertaste shows a good complexity with a lot of good earthy flavours at first with alcohol showing soon afterwards and some nice oaky characteristics. Overall, a nice pungent and complex scottish that shows very well - perhaps one of the best Ive had from the style ever. I sampled this 341 mL bottle purchased from Best Cellars in Arlington, Virginia (Since closed) on 04-July-2011 for US$7.99 sampled in New Paltz, New York on 10-December-2011. Bottled Since Feb 1, 2010? (on bottom of bottle).

A 1 year old, 341 ml bottle. Pours a very deep, dark red, which from some angles looks brown, almost black but from others, looks ruby red. Very foggy, with a persistent orange-beige head. Tastes a bit like smoke, toffee and oak. Very little after taste, almost no perceptible bitterness. Texture is extremely interesting: one of the thickest, creamiest ales Ive had. Alcohol is almost imperceptible. Im giving it big props for its mouthfeel, however it would be almost perfect if it could only taste a tad bit...more.

Ça sent la mère et le sucre!  Délicieuse odeur, une invitation à la dégustation.  
Très peu de mousse, une robe opaque et rougeoyante.  
Goût de Malt caramélisé avec un petit côté salin typique des bière de cette brasserie.  Le résultat nest pas vilain mais il est nest pas aussi réussi que dans la Corp Mort. Un peu huileuse.  
Arrière goût : on y sent peu damertume, la chaleur de lalcool et le sel.  Le reflux est bien mais il y a un arrière goût tenace vaguement déplaisant de sel de mer qui ne part pas. 

Cette bière est extrêmement bien cotée mais je suis déçu.  Le coté salin de la bière nuit à cette scotch ale alors que je ladore dans La corps mort.  Une déception compte tenu des attentes mais quand même une bière à découvrir.

De couleur rouge-rubis avec un mince col beige. Des odeurs dherbe, de fleurs, de plantes, de caramel au beurre et de cannelle qui sen dégagent sont tellement agréables. En bouche, elle semble nous avertir quelle prendra de la place. Des saveurs de miel de sarrasin, décorce darbre, de cerises mûres et pain kamut grillé se signalent. Vraiment un beau produit. (300911)
UPDATED: OCT 20, 2012 Belle grosse bombe malté et sucré avec une généreuse présence de fruits confits.

Bottle @mondial de la bière. A clear amber brown beer, nose is light and slightly fruity on raspberry. Aroma is on fruit yeast, smoked notes, caramel, medium sweet, light body, very disappointed. Completely overrated.

Bouteille 341 ml., 1 an dâge. Dans un ballon. Belle mousse couleur marais assez persistante. Arômes de banane, clou de girofle et cannelle sintensifiant après chaque gorgée. Sucrée en bouche, houblon imperceptible. Arrière goût de chocolat très doux, légèrement de pain grillé. Excellente bière, mais son prix exorbitant nest aucunement justifié! 7$ pour une petite, il faut pas charier non plus.

A: The beer pours a hazy mahogany color with a finger of khaki head.

S: Lots of sweet, toffee and brown sugar aromas to start off.  Very strong dark fruits notes, especially raisins, cherries, and plums.  Toward the back end, there is a bit of vanilla and some oak as well.

T: Like the aroma, quite sweet.  The vanilla character is strong, but theres still plenty of toffee, brown sugar, and caramel.  A little bit of toasted bread with just a mild booze note.  Sweet raisins and plums are also present.

M: Medium in body with low to medium carbonation.

O: Perhaps a touch too sweet, but overall quite nice.  And Im not usually a big Scotch Ale fan.

Bottle. An unclear, ruby-ish brown beer with a finger-thick beige head. Its aroma is filled with dried fruits and maltyness, some spices and dark LME, meaty too. Well, its nice, but a bit one-dimensional. Its full-bodied and slightly spiced and bitter, rather dry and with a soft and low level of carbonation. Rather pleasant and tasteful, although I miss some more complexity. 110720

Bottle 500ml @ yngwie
Pours clear dark amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt and caramel. Taste is heavy sweet and light bitter. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.
Bottle.Pours deep amber with on off-white head.Aroma of sweet malt, grains, fruitiness, cola and alcohol.Flavor is sweet and malt with some grains and yeast.Medium to full body, average carbonation.

Bottle from State Line.  Pours turbid burnt sienna with minimal khaki head.  Nose is scotch malt, red vinous fruit, brown sugar, yeasty, hops.  Tastes a bit like a Flemish red, with a heavy red vinous and figgy fruit flavor, not sweet, pretty thick palate with low carbonation.  Also has backup hops.  Comes off like a triple hybrid of Flemish sour, malty scotch ale, and grand cru.  Complexity abounds.

Bottle thanks to Alex... Medium brown, nice color, light tan head... Very malty, a bit of bo and peat, ok... The taste is just off, salty as Alex described, with a bit of body order, not a fan of this

Stark malzig-süßer Antrunk mit langsam aufsteigender Würze, an die der Alkohol gekoppelt zu sein scheint. Der Süße Ton weicht etwas, das Malz geht in eine röstmalzerne Richtung. Trockener und etwas kratziger Nachgeschmack. 	 
Test vom 10.9.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 10,11,9,10,10,10 - 10,00

bottle from 2007. Perhaps past its prime, but still not too bad. Deeper caramel pour. Rich malts,light cinnamon,  light wood & whiskey in the aroma. Notes of vanilla, oak, rich maltiness, whiskey in the flavor, seemed more barleywine like than scotch ale. Wish i would of corked this earlier

Bottle brought the isles from my sister-in-law; dark brown with red hues and medium tan head; aroma-very sweet and pleasant caramel, toffee, cinnamon, mild hops; taste-heavy sweetness, salty, lightly bitter, mild carbonation. I am going to let the rest of my 6 pack age a little!

On tap at Churchkey. Served in a snifter.

Pour yields a very dark-bodied brew with a half-finger light tan head, which quickly recedes, falling into a thin collar. The nose pushes forward with a very nice malty sweetness, reminding most of a combination of molasses and brown sugar with a hint of caramel thrown in for good measure. A slight amount of booze backs that up. There is a light earthiness to it as well.

The flavor is a bit of a departure from the nose, and not in tye best way. The mingling of elements is gone, leading instead a medium body containing merely a good dose of sweet malt. Not quite cloying, but not super-enjoyable considering how one-dimensional it is. There is a bit of light earth and booze in the finish as well. Low carbonation. Pretty decent, but not something I would come back to.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 04-05-2011

341ml bottle from trade (thanks cfrancis). Pours a deep red tinged cola brown with half inch of persistent khaki head. Aroma is lush and slightly boozy. Cola notes, cocoa, cherries, sweet candy malt, caramel...lush to say the least. Flavour is deep and rewarding with cereal and caramel malt, some molasses, cola, aged fruitcake, vanilla. Virtually a hybrid between a scotch ale and a stout. Lovely.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2016 One of Quebecs more unique beers.  Pours a dark ruby brown, 1 finger head.  Smell of Molasses, Dried dark berries, bitter chocolate, raisins, Caramel.  Taste:  Dark Fruit (dried plum, raisin, blueberry), bit of booze, Brown sugar, molasses, Hint of English black licquorice and coffee - let this warm up a bit as theres a lot going on!  More of a sipper than a drinker, but still quite good.  Throw a couple into your basket next time youre at Peluso!

Pour cola brown small white head. Aroma winter spice, vanilla, oak, malt, caramel, toffee, coca cola gummies, touch boozy. Taste wood, oak, vanilla, caramel, toffee, dark fruit, winter spices. MF medium to full body nice mild carb. Excellent beer very well brewed.

Deep brown pour with a thick, sticky off white/tan head. The aroma has a lovely, briny character over a rich toffeeish malt base. A little bit of light fruit (blackberry, cherry) along with a kiss of lightly salty whisky. Faint vanilla and caramel contribute a touch of sweetness. Soft and briny with a touch of light alcohol on the finish. There is a nice complexity to this brew with a whole lot going on yet it maintains a finesse. Warming brings up more vanilla and caramel, lending an almost rye/bourbony flavour. Lovely stuff.
Tiens, la soeur et le beauf viennent souper ce soir.  Histoire de le faire sentir cheap pour la prochaine fois; je lui sert cette luxuriante et saline scotch ale.  Au plaisir de me faire recevoir!

Nose is smoke and toffee and almost salty. Taste is salty, with some caramel and some hops. Not even a little bit sweet, definitely  a new take on scotch ale, considering the lack of sweetness. Really nice definitely recommend it to everyone.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2012 pours dark reddish brown without a head. dark fruits, malts, peat smoke, alcohol (should have been aged much more), toffee (not very caramely like most scotch ales) and a grassy and pungent hoppy profile all the way through. beer is oddly (i guess in a good way...!) sour, acidic, bitter, and a tad sweet. imperial porter tones. sticky mouthfeel, very low carbonation - great. very interesting and good.
Good scotch ale, you can almost taste the seashore from les Iles de la madeleine. Complex taste, sweet, caramel with some bitterness. Hard to describe, but so good to drink.

Caramel Malty and sweet aroma. Dark brown with very little head that quickly dissipates upon pouring into the glass. Taste is slightly sweet, bitter, and sour all in one. The body is light to medium, with soft carbonation and a thin and sticky texture. Overall the beer is good for the most part, and for me someone who is not a big fan of Scotch Ales this was a big step up for me. A nice new beer that I just randomly beer, though not worth the money that I payed for it.

Pours a very dark brown colour, but still visibly clear with a beige head that dissipates. Aroma is of caramel malts, vanilla with a little oak and spices. Taste is sweet and slightly malty throughout with a dry bitter finish. Full body, average carbonation, and creamy on the palate. Overall a very good scotch ale and beer.

A reddish brown ale with no headé A superb aroma of licorice, plums, dark fruits, fruity esters, banana, raisins and warming alcohol. In mouth, a smooth, rich and complex ale with nice treacle toffee, raisinsm light coffee, and bitter roots, smooth and enticing. On tap at Vices et Versa, Nov. 12 2010.

Bottle in a trade.  Pours a bruin body with a tan head.  Malty body with caramel and toasted malt.  A faint smokiness with a touch of birch, and light woodiness.  Mildly sweet with a mild warming and a chewy but drying finish.  Nice offering.

On tap at Birch & Barley.  Pours clear deep dark brown with a slight tan head on the beer.  The aroma is that of a well-done Scotch Ale, with caramel, nuts, vanilla, roast, and peat smoke.  The flavor has big caramel malt and nuttiness, considerable malty sweetness and peat.  Tasty.  Medium-full bodied and smooth with softer carbonation.  A very good Canadian Scotch Ale overall.
Bottle. Pours dark brown, almost black. Nose and taste of fig, molasses and brown sugar. Some barley. Dry chalky finish.

12 oz bottle.  Deep cola brown, clear at the edges, with a pocked beige head.  Nose is toffee, nutmeg, almond and vanilla.  Medium body with lively prickles.  Taste is molasses and nougat balanced by burnt sugar, peat and greens.  A bit abrupt in its bitterness but mellows nicely.
The smell is nice it smell a little like smoke. The taste is like rubber I dont know if the bottle is infected but I should try it an other time to know if this is really the taste of this beer.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of malt, caramel, light smoke, light toffee, slight root vegetables, and a hint of peat.  Poured brown/red in color with a small, beige/light brown head that greatly diminished but lasted throughout as a film on top of the beer, as well as around the edges.  Slightly hazy.  Very slightly sparkling.  Flavor is light to medium sweet.  Tastes of malt, caramelized sugar, burnt caramel, slight smoke, light toffee, slight chocolate, and light wood.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Average carbonation.  Medium sweet, malt, burnt caramel, and slight wood finish.  9%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

Bottle. pours a dark brown with a tall delicious creamy light brown/khaki head.  Delicious aroma, thats hard to describe--hoppy, a bit woody, creamy... i really just cant describe it, its damn delicious though.  The flavor is the same, with a bit of roastiness.  Extremely well balanced and very little to no alcohol flavor.  I could drink this shit all day!!  Medium to full bodied with low carbonation.  Overall: this is just an amazingly delicious likable beer, for beer geeks and normal folks alike.

12 ounce bottle shared by footbalm. Pours a dark cloudy burgundy hue with a medium off-white head. The aroma is huge spices and caramel. A dry spicy flavor, almost like pumpkin, sweet caramel, dusty malts. Nice. Pretty light and easy.

Bière brune foncée très forte, 9 % dalcool. Goût surprenant et intéressant. On y goûte bien le malt et malgré sa haute teneur dalcool, le goût reste agréable et cest une douceur dans la bouche. Jaurais eu tendance à boire un liquide crémeux semblable à de la mélasse, mais sans exagéré.

Bottle, tfs Menno!
Hazy reddish brown, tiny head.
Aroma is a weird winy fruity spicyness.
Flavour is sugary fruity wine, aftertaste is better with caramel, malt and faint hops. Weird but ok.

Bottle, thanks for sharing, Menno! Clear dark copper pour, thin off-white head. Aroma of fruits, oak, candy sugar and port. Flavor is slightly bitter, slightly sweet, slightly sour in a nice balance. Somewhat rusty and sharp as well. Watery texture and average carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2011 Bouteille 341 ml. 9.0%. Couleur ambrée-rousse très foncée. Arôme assez complexe de caramel, noisettes, malt, brandy, bois. Goût de noix de chêne, alcool et malt..prunes noires mûres. Une légère amertume en finale. Du bonbon.

Had this at the Grand Tasting during RBSG courtesy of Rastacouere.  Pours a clear amber with a thin white head.  Smoked almonds, tamarind and soy sauce.  Lots of smoke, more smoked almonds.  A bit sweet.  Interesting.

Bottled. Dark amber coloured. Fluffy light brown head. Aroma of spice, caramel, brown sugar, vague smoke. Flavour of spice, sweetness, herbs, caramel, light bread and actually quite meaty. Flavour signiicantly better than aroma. Medium to full bodied. Dry herbal and sweet bitterness in the end. Thx. to SS Boutip for this.

Mahogany and clear with small medium tan head. Woody and herbal aromas with forest and minerally stone. Taste replays all this with an excellent dry feel and some pale fruit playing under it. Kind of the Orval of Scotch Ales.
341ml bottle. Seaport Beer Fest. Maybe my favourite at the festival. Full of spice and wood character on the nose and in the mouth.

Rich, malty caramel aroma with a light dose of smokiness, dates, toasted nuts.   Flavor is drier than I was expecting but still leaves a not-sweet-yet-treacly impression on the palate with some pumpkin pie spices.  Not bad, but I will not be seeking out another one.

Thin tan head, short lived, lacing is nil. Clear chestnut colored brew. Malty nose, light smoke, dish soap, caramel. Medium bodied, lightly oily on the palate, hint astringent with a low carbonation. Lightly sweet malt flavors, soapy, caramelly notes, earthy with notes of allspice and or nutmeg. Lightly sweet finish, malty, light astringency. Meh. Not sure why i bought it? Very expensive and no where near worth the asking price. Insane. Bottle procured @statelinliquors.
yummy and interesting. toffee, butterscotch, maple syrup, smooth with a hint of hoppy dryness and spices. really learning to like this style.

341 ml bottle from jsprime. pours burgundy with a minimal tan head. minimal carbonation. the aroma is very spice forward, dark fruits come in after. the flavour is quite complex. deep malt structure, dark fruits and spice with a touch of smoke. balanced but no hop flavour, the bitterness could very well be roasted malt. long drying finish. quite good.

Aroma is caramel, a hint of hay, with a somewhat roasty feel to it -- there are even some fruit notes (pineapple, banana) popping up! Some interesting hints of raisins in mouth, and I suspect there are some smoked malts in it. Great, great, great!!! Pricey, but worth it. I wonder if its as expansive on the Iles-de-la-Madeleine...

Bottle. Pours a beautiful deep mahogany with a sponge toffee head that shows nice retention. Aroma is mouthwatering: rich melted toffee, burnt sugar, brown bread crusts and hints of spices. Rich, intensely flavourful palate of burnt sugar, molasses, brown bread, prunes, caramelized banana, and spicy nuances. Not even a hint of the 9% ABV. I drank this in about 10 minutes and wanted more. Absolutely fantastic.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Good thing La Trappe à Fromage was selling these individually, because this one is a 9% ABV Scotch ale that is quite expensive. Bottled February 2009. Pours a red-mohagony colour with a beige head that is foamy, has good retention and creates beautiful spotted lace. Interesting aromas of mild smoke, bananas, some vegetables, caramel malt and dark fruits (prunes, raisins). Smooth mouthfeel, but leaves kind of a feeling, after you ate a banana, on your tongue - like tart, tannin. The taste is still pretty complex, but not as powerful as the smell. No sign of that strong alcohol, no burn at all. Mild scotch whiskey, caramel, oak, light smoke and the bananas again. Quite an "interesting" Scotch ale that is worth trying.
10.05.06 Bottle 2009 version. Clear ruby soft carb. A:Anise, caramel F:moderate bitterness, full bodyied, sweet but well balanced by bitterness. From memory I prefer early version

12oz bottle at the DC Local tasting.  Pours a totally clear, mahogany brown with one clump of white head.  Big brown sugar aroma, spice, maple, rum aromas.  Flavor is sweet, some spruce, light pine.  Finish is full bodied and sweet.

341ml bottle, shared.  Small beige head atop crystal clear copper body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, cantaloupe, some vinous.  Taste is sweet, caramel, spicy, light alcohol burn.  Sticky medium-full body, low carbonation.

Bottle at DC local tasting, courtesy of Lenny - thanks, man.  Dark copper color, no head to speak of.  Aroma of cinnamon flavored jawbreakers.  Taste is heavily spiced, with shades of scotch.  Interesting.

Bière brune. Arôme complexe et très puissante. Rubis en verre avec un collet ocre qui se dissipe sans attendre. Doit se faire apprivoiser : la première gorgée ne reflète pas bien le plaisir qui suivra. Prix trop élevé néanmoins, 6.79$ en 330 cl. Conséquence fâcheuse de la mode des bières onéreuses.

Bière brune aux reflets rouge rubis.  Mousse couleur amande foncée.  Collet qui tombe rapidement.  Faible effervescence.  Arômes et goût exaltants de malt rôti, de caramel et de tourbe.  Touche de fumée avec en finale la présence discrète de raisin et de noix.  En résumé, très bonne scotch ale.

Deep amber colo with a rich foamy beige head. What an aroma! Smells of toffey, caramel and banana.  Full complexity in the taste. Layers of toffey, brown sugar and molass erupting on my tasting buds. Also notes of smokey malt. Wow. Not enough distribution in Montreals region. Expensive but worth the price!

Pours a granite with an almond head.  Aroma is a beautiful whiskey, malty tickle.  Taste is strong with caramel, scotch whiskey and an aftertaste of spice.  Really nice balanced beer that Ill have again.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2010 09 Bottle thanks to Glouglouburp!Red-mahogany with a thin beige head that disappears. Nose is strong malt, tea, and caramel.Flavor has more caramel, malt, tobacco.Thin body, lightly alcoholic, but a nice, lengthy malt and burnt chocolate finish. Great stuff...can only imagine what the06 tastes like at this point.

Acquired via trade thanks to glougobrup. Thanks Dany. This bottle may have been infected, but it worked very well. Pours a deep red with a small tan head. The aroma is all over the place. Malty, oaky, smokey and hints of red licorice. The taste is very different from the nose. Red licorice, oak, chocolate, smoke, chestnut, and a long bitter finish. The brett just makes this beer. Intentional or not. Thanks Dany!

bottle from Le Gobelet. out of tulip, pours a dark amber with a gorgeous, creamy off white heads that left loads of lacing. bouquet of sweet caramel and pumpkin blow up in your face, a very powerful and intense aroma! smoked wood and dark fruit in there as well. taste is sweet malts and spices, bread and caramel. palate is balanced well. a very good beer, but expensive.

Poured a crystal clear, dark, reddish-amber hue with very little head.  Very intriguing, powerful aroma of smoked woodiness, caramels and sweet fruits.  Taste is surprising in that all the character noted in the aroma is present, although the sweet notes are curbed by a nicely balanced level of dry bitterness that follows through to the finish.  Palate is pleasantly creamy and almost sticky at the same time.  Alcohol content is well disguised.  A unique and refreshing brew!

2009 Bottle - Thanks Glouglouburp!! - Pours dark amber and almost clear with a small beige head that lingers...aroma is very inviting, sweet apple, cherry, dirt/grain, some light smoke and holiday spice?...flavour has all of that but is much more dry, bitter hops and burnt caramel, green apple skin and some peat moss...very tasty stuff!

Bottle, many thanks to hobbersr. Nose is red rope licorice, acid, tartness, apple, dry aromatic malt, and acetic acid. Flavors are much darker, smoky, rich, tart, but still delicate. A great blend of fruity, smoky, and sour. Pretty awesome.

Bottle from Bonisoir, Montreal. Been wanting to try this one for a while and had heard that this most recent batch was an improvement (even if not up to the apparent standard of the original version). Gushed everywhere on opening, but settled into a fairly handsome amber pour with soft foam and lacing. Aroma was initially off-putting, damn close to a Bloody Mary. Some sweet malts and spices in there but its certainly quite an odd Scotch to start. Tannins and tang, with some light breads and a fruit combo of stewed tomatoes and pear. Odd.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2009 Surprised that this bottle foamed on opening! Settles down quickly in the glass. Soft foam on mohogany. Dark caramel aroma with a hint of molasses and an unexpected spice in the background. Definate alcohol in the flavour. A bit of a baking soda edge and foamy feel. Burnt toffee charachter and finish. Belgian Scotch Ale.

A deep garnet pours a frothy beige cap. Some spotty lace. Nose is intense, smokey peat, burnt caramel, brown sugar, rye bread, spicy hops. Tastes of sweet burnt caramel malts, prunes, smoked peat, cinnamon, some vanilla, dark bread.A sipper. A bit of heft in the finish with an astringent boozey finale. Excellent.
12oz bottle, 2007 release. pours clear ruby with off white head. the nose is bready, yeast cakey. flavors are bready, toffee, malty, and a touch peaty. age has really dulled this one.

Bottle at home - thanks to Mikkel for bringing it to DK. Clear red/amber - white head. Sweetness, raisins, berries, peppery, wood, light hoppy, spicy, caramel, high malty, nice hoppy, chocolate, Nice body.

12oz bottle 񢉗).  thanks to andrew for sharing..... pours a dark caramel , semi-transparent, with a wispy, thin slightly off-white head.... semi-oxidized caramel malts with hints of peat .... semi-watery yet creamy papery caramel malt.  light and fluffy mouthfeel and cant seem to tell that its 9%.
Belle couleur cuivrée. Un bon goût prononcé de scotch avec un arrière goût caramélisée. Faible arrière goût acre. Peu de mousse.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2010 1 Year aged, tasted side by side with equally aged Mcewans scotch ale. Aroma is very strawberry, butter, anise, hops, chocolate, roses, wow.  Taste is dark chocolate, strawberries, hops. Mouthfeel is clear but the taste is up to it. Really depends on the vintage and ageing.

Sampled old (8.7 %) and new (9%) versions vertically at Timo As. This rating is for the older version which I prefer. Hazy dark ruby color with creamy beige head. Thick, sweet, malty, vinous and berryish aroma with red currants, toffee and chocolate. Sweet flavors of toffee, caramel, toasted bread and red currants. Smooth thick milk shake like palate. This is much smoother, thicker and barley wine like than the new version.  

Rating for the new version: Ruby color. The aroma and flavor is malty, nutty, toasty, toffeish and warming. Good malty ale. 7-4-7-4-14.

Bottle from glouglouburp.  Thanks again Dany!  Bottle pours brown with ruby red highlights.  Aroma is potent and invitiing.  Chocolate, maple syrup, brown sugar, dates, and toffee.  Flavor is some sweet malts, bitter chocolate, and pretty well balanced.  Not overly sweet. Slight touch of alcohol, but quite complimentary.    Really impressed with how smooth and accessible this beer is.  The alc.  is a perfect compliment to this treat of a beer. Awesome.    I want to have this again!

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2009 Robe rubis. Arômes dérables et dalcool fruité. Mélange de scotch ale et de quadrupel. Très bonne bière aux saveurs de caramel, de sirop dérable, de fruits rouge et dalcool. Très bonne finale de caramel, toffe. Une des meilleures bière que jai dégusté provenant du Québec.

341 ml bottle from Trappe a Fromage, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. AP 08/09.
App.:  Clear deep copper, fair tan foam.
  
Aroma:  Bright and tangy, some cherries, some light warm spices and roasted malts (sweet), is this bordering on infected?
  
Palate:  Medium body, moderate effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Slightly tangy malts, dark dried fruits, cola-like herbals, light bright fruitiness, some light warm spices, ginger?; sweet with fair bitterness and some spicy malts left over.

Didnt quite live up to my $5.49-induced expectations...

341ml bottle acquired in trade with Sammy (thanks!). Poured a deeper amberish/copper color with a huge sized off white head. Aromas of smoke, earthiness, caramel, and I was getting some spices in there too (cinnamon and maybe some ginger). Tastes of the same spiciness, toasted caremel, some brown sugariness, and earthy. Alcohol content hidden.

This beer has a very nice color and smell, but the first sip gives a mouthfull of flavours! Im pretty difficult with beers but this one is a keeper. I have the chance to live right next this Microbrewery and with time and patience I keep my "corne de brume" and let it age a year before I drink it... well parts of it! This beer ages incredebly well!

Clear, dark brown brew that produced a very nice bright tan head (actually the colour is somewhat strange) about one thumb thick, tons of 360 degree lacing, decent surface coverage left over. The aroma is very interesting and unlike anything Ive had before: firstly, I can detect the tomato that some others have noted (thx), brown sugar with the sweetness kept under control, dark berries that seem smoked, caramel, prune?, some kind of cooking chocolate, biscuit, interesting spice that only reminds me of a very candied version of spices found in the typical Speyside Whiskey. The aroma is ever changing as well while never producing an "off" smell. The flavour is not as interesting but still very appealing. More tomato juice mixed in with a healthy dose of well chosen spices (most obvious is licorice), roasted malts tied directly to the overall sweetness, salt... this gets more and more like Mottss Garden Cocktail which is much spicier than V8, plums, peat - all in no particular order. The only impression of alcohol that I get is loosely found in the lingering after taste. As I go Ive noticed that this beer sometimes comes across thinner than I assume. Nice subtle sweet yet spicy grain finish with slight chocolate that I can only notice as the lingering goodness begins to wane. I picked this one up randomly and damn it if I didnt chose one of the best beers Ive had in months.

Bottle - 341ml. Dark amber body with low carbonation and a lasting beige foamy head. Strong malty/hoppy aroma with caramel and cinnamon hints. Alcohol is well hidden. Well balanced hoppy taste with roasty, caramel and plummy notes. Ends with a warming bittersweet finish. Enjoyable 1400th rating!

Very dark brown pour with minimal light tan head that leaves a spotty lacing. Aroma is smoky caramel malt that lingers in its sweetness. Brown sugar, dark fruit and molasses come through as well. Flavor is a typical Scotch Ale malt bomb with tons of roasted malt, sweet molasses and brown sugary sweetness that ends with significant fruity notes. Palate is medium to full with a very dry finish. Very enjoyable.

Dark brown pour with reddish tints and a small white head. Aroma starts with a caramel and dark fruit, then lightens to notes of peach and spice. Flavor is very nice- brown sugar, and dark fruit, that again lightens, though the finish is now definitely an idea of peach and apricot. Complex, really nice scotch ale.

341ml, bottled Feb 09, with another thanks to Glouglouburp!  Pours a clear dark amber with a large and lasting tan head.  Aroma is ripe fruits, spice, toasted malts, bread, light smoke, and some brown sugar; lots going on here.  Flavor is equally interesting, with more spice, brown sugar, dark fruits and toasted and bready malts.  Good stuff for sure, thanks again Dany!

Bottle sampled on 5/22/08 courtesy of wetherel: Pours a transparent bright copper orange with a spotty-lacing white head.  Aroma of sweet toasty caramel malts with a hint of peat and light fruits.  Body starts fairly full and sweet caramely malty with a hint of earthy smoke and light fruits before a drier slightly warming finish.  A nice Scotch ale.

Aroma of ripe figs, and dates, brown sugar, bready malt, alcohol, and a touch of port. Flavor is sweet, but also savory. Nice notes of smoke, and ripe fruit, with some sweet malt in the finish. awesome stuff.

341 mL bottle.  2009 vintage.  Deep ruby brown with a small beige head.  The aroma is complex and appealing, with brown sugar, ripe berries, spice, alcohol and licorice.  The flavour is big, with more bitter licorice, caramel, roast, and dates.  Mild alcohol burn in the finish. Full body.   Excellent brew.
Bottle courtesy of boutip.  Pours brown with a thin tan head.  Smells of roses, fruity, some peaty hints, earthy.  Tastes lightly bitter, earthy, spicy, lightly citrussy.  Very palatable.

Bottle thx to Daknole. Deep rich chestnut color, lovely hue with scant tan head. Aroma is V8 juice, strong. The tomato is almost overpowering. Smooth palate has the vegetal flavor too, not offensive but distinct, lingering vegetal flavors. No smoke at all. A very odd experience.

My NE/Canada beer hookup Jay sent this.  Pours a chestnut brown with a yellow/tan head.  Aroma is kind of odd..I get V-8 juice, fresh yellow squash, malt, and toffeee.  Flavor is sweet, more squash, with a slightly bitter finish.  I liked this.  Then I didnt.  Then I did again.  Very interesting but odd.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2011 Bottle. Dark red-brown with a thin moka head with poor retention.  Aroma is very sweet with cherries, toffee, berries, brown suger, roasted malt and a hint of smoke. Flavor is a little less fruity than the aroma. There iscaramel, peat, nuts, wood, roasted malt, chocolate, brown sugar, dark honey and some grass. Full body with an oily mouthfeel and medium carbonation. An awesome but overpriced scotch ale.

Bottle with appreciation to boutip.  Pours a dark cherry wood finish with a small tan head.  Aromas are a sweet mix of brown sugar, dark fruit and a touch of peat.  Flavor is very good and this is my new favorite Scotch Ale.  (If only I could get it regularly and inexpensively...)  Anyhow, the peat and smoke flavors come through very nicely and play off the sugar and fruit.  At the same time, there is a bit of a nut flavor that helps smooth things out.  Im guessing that my attraction to this is the simple fact that the sweetness is held in check so nicely... unlike so many other scotch ales Ive tried that end up just being a cloying mess.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 341mL bottle, bottled November 07--I still have another from the previous batch as well, which I will rerate soon.  Clear copper with a 1 1/2 finger beige head, good retention.  Lots of caramel with a good amount of maple.  The flavor is much the same with a hint of earth toward the finish.  There was also a bit of almond.  Some light oxidation and alcohol is present.  The finish is semi-dry with just a little bit of roasty malt bitterness.  Lightly carbonated with a medium body.  Pretty good--wish it had a little peat in it, though I know it isnt required.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Murky brown with thin quickly disappearing beige head. Strong roasted oak whiskey vanilla nut aroma. Strong dry whiskey woody vanilla tobacco raisin nut malt. Too strong on the whiskey but somehow the other flavours still stand out. Nice aftertaste of woody vanilla tobacco. Never had a Scotch Ale that was dry instead of sweet, must  be from woodiness.

Bottle, picked up from La Trappe à Fromage on the Hull side just a short drive out of Ottawa. Aside from my expectations of a scotch ales aroma, my nose detects figs and raisins. Love how this coats my mouth, no one flavour overwhelms the next, good balance. Lasting flavour varying from bittersweet chocolate, malt, honey. Finish is dry. I think I really like this one

Acheté à la trappe à fromage de g
Hull et dégusté avec Glandine et Agaguk dans un verre de blonde dachouffe. Apparence brune ambré au reflet rubis avec une fine couche de mousse. Arômes de mélasse, cerise et confiture de fraise et une touche de réglisse noir. Goût de (jack daniels) , alcool , caramel, date, hichory et fûmé de bois de chêne. Une bière incroyable remplis de trésor...

341ml Bottle shared with Grand Genies. Clear ruby brown appearance with minimal taned head.  Aroma: soya, cherrys, molasses, strawberry jam, licorice, caramel and dryed raisins.  Flavor: alcohol (Jack Daniels), caramel,  dates, hicorice and smoky pine.  Palate: medium body, soft carbonation, silky with alcohol finish.

341ml bottle. From notes, Aroma is dark fruits, cherries. Taste is like aroma. I did not enjoy the previous Scotch Ales i tasted but this is very much to my liking. Awesome balance, perfect until the end. Will add more details to this rating with the other bottle I have. Rating #76

Thanks so much to HogTownHarry. Appearance: Dark brown with a large tan head which is at least two fingers in size. Aroma: Caramel, mint, sugar, toffee, milk, ginger, pine finish. Flavour Malt, pine,hops, whiskey, smoke, alcohol, grass, burnt malt with a long malty finish. Lovely.

Bottle, $7.99 Canadian Dollars; had been sitting in my fridge for three months!  Pours dark brown with a beautiful tan head.  Aroma has wood, bourbon, figs, esters and some dark chocolate; very complex and attractive.  Flavor is rich and malty, with a smooth palate that perfectly displays the rich flavor of this brew.  Nutty initial palate, complemented by dark fruit, oak, and earthiness.   Finish shows nuts, brown sugar, and light floral hopping.  Flavors are extremely well-balanced, and quite luxurious.  This is definitely the best-tasting scotch ale Ive ever had.

Bouteille brune, 341ml, embouteillée 15 mois auparavant.  Arômes complexes, mais très équilibrés de caramel, sucre dorge, mélasse et fruits (fraises cuites).  Liquide bourgogne présentant un moyen col de mousse crémeuse qui disparaît lentement.  En bouche, je remarque rapidement des petites notes de tabac.  Cest principalement sucré , mais pas trop pour le style.  Je remarque des saveurs de mélasse/chocolat et du fruité (fraises cuites comme dans tarte aux fraises).  On goûte peu lalcool (9%), mais celui-ci est quand même réconfortant.  Il y a également une légère amertume de levure en arrière-goût.  Le corps est moyen et il y a peu deffervescence.  Bière idéale lors dune soirée froide dhiver.  Se boit très facilement !  Très bien fait, mais très dispendieuse (8$ la bouteille !)

Bottle at Madsberg tasting 2008. Pours red-brown with a nice, staying, creamy, beige film head. Aroma is malty, rye bread, lightly vinious. Fine mouthfeel. Flavour is very malty, rye, doughy, light chocolate and a great, dry finish. Very pleasant.
Hazy mahogany with a medium beige head. .got rosasted malt in the nose along with chocolate and caramel. Flavour was sweet with  plenty of port and toasted malt. Finished sweet.

Bottle.
Cloudy red brown coloured with a medium sized beige head.
Sweet aroma of caramel and dried fruits with notes of whisky.
Sweet flavour of caramel, fruits and dried fruits with notes of whisky.
Sweet and warming alcoholic finish.

50 cL bottle. Pours hazy dark brown with a creamy, tan and dense head. Dry and mild spiced to vague butterscotch aroma. Sweet malty, light roasted and subdued oxidised and mild fruity flavoured. Light breadish and sweet caramel malty. Lasting sweet and caramel malty finish. Nice one.

Bonne scotch ale, brune avec reflets rougeatres, notes de caramel et de sel.
Bonne mais pas exceptionnelle, over-rater et ben trop chere.

Good scotch ale, brown color with reddish-like highlights, taste of caramel and salt. Good but definetely not exceptionnal, totally over-rated and way to priced.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2009 Rerate: 3-18-09.

Pours reddish brown, medium khaki head.
Aroma - peanut butter, malt, rubber, perhaps caramel, and the most curious whiff of strawberry jam finds its way in as well. Well carbonated, full body. Wow, this unexpected strawberry jam impression comes through very strong in the flavor amid the more traditional caramelly malt flavors. I didnt pick this out the first time trying this beer, but this is incredibly unique, and quite a delight. Builds on a base of earthy underbrushy bitterness, almost hoppy. Aftertaste of pumpernickel or rye or some such. This bottle is performing significantly better than the previous one. Overall, well made, enjoyable, gives me a new look on the style. I personally enjoy Founders Backwoods Bastard more, though thats quite a different take.

8 4 8 4 16, 4.0

Orig. rating: 12-11-08.

Pours clear nut brown, light head. Bottled Nov 2007. Nutty aroma. Flavor - peanut butter?? warming, bitter. slightly oily. Good.

7 3 7 3 15, 3.5

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2009 Simply amazing and outstanding.  6.29 for 341 ml is quite expensive for a Québec-made beer bought in Montreal...  When it is as good as this, who could care about the price... Exquisite aroma, not as dark as most scotch ales.  Barely a trace of alchool in the taste with a lot of subtilities and complexity in the warmth of this divine brew.  Sweetness, caramel-like and a discreet bitterness. Keep up with your excellent work, Biere des iles.  I love you, Madelinots.  Added: Guilty as charged, though; I over-rated that one. A quite too watery texture and, though pretty well balanced, nothing is oustanding in the taste.
Tres belle couleur orange foncé à tête dorée.   Exellent mariage entre le caramel et le bitter.  Probablement la meilleur Scotch ale brassé au Canada(avec la McAuslan).

12 oz. bottle - thanks a bunch biegman for making the extra effort for this; pours rich brown with thin white head; mostly clear with considerable lacing going down; aromas of sweet caramel, but almost a little like ethanol too; very thin body and a little sweet; improved a little, but this was kind of an odd one overall

This is simply the best beer i have ever drinked.... a pefect mix between a prestine scotch ale with slight caramel taste and a very bitter beer ( about 60 IBU ).This beer takes 6 months to ferment so it can only distribute soo much wich explains somewhat the cost of this golden-reddish delight. A must for beer lovers !!

The notorious "new" batch.  Cold clean red.  Chocolate soda fountain, root beer candy, wet earth, alcohol aroma.  Raspberries in vanilla.  Sugary, damp, and distantly salty.  Salted rye bread.  Raw.

Coarse wooden chocolate flavor.  Not rich and bold like an earthy, semisweet, mostly real cocoa chocolate, but dry and sugary like an extract syrup.  The fruit character is bitter and tannic, like the skin of a plum or a dried date.  Smooth, velvety almond sweetness in a rich and sharp spirit-like texture, with plenty of mapley woodiness.  Still unpolished.  No subtlety in the delivery.

Medium-full palate is softly carbonated and surprisingly not sticky.  Tinny mineral bitterness precedes a lasting, dry rubbing of alcohol and caramelized almonds in the finish.  Rather frustrating.  Its redeeming qualities are ever present, but suffocated, and what might be most annoying is that there isn’t some obvious flaw lending the weight.  It just never quite arrives.  Dany was right.  Thanks man!

Bouteille de 341 ml achetée à la Saucisserie BDF (Bois-des-Filion, QC). Arôme: Odeur de caramel et de raisins. Apparence: La couleur est brune rougâtre avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel et de petits fruits. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture minérale.Forte effervescence en bouche. Présence de caramel en arrière goût. (Rating #1748)

Shared by kmweaver.  Pours a clear but dark caramel copper color with a tan head.  Viscous and oily legs cling to the glass and give off a sort of green hue.  Nose is toffee liqueur and caramel malt, along with toasted bread and light notes of chocolate (chocolate liqueur).  Tannic flavor, coarse and toast-heavy, medium level of alcohol noticed.  Toffee and bread tend to dominate, along with quieter notes of maple and brown sugar and wood.  Amaretto finish (semi-sweet) is nice.

341mL bottle, newest batch (I believe), courtesy of Glouglouburp.  Thanks, Dany!  Pours a bright, clear and viscous golden-amber color; light tan head with fine-bubbled lacing.  Some nuttiness, dried red fruits, candy sugar, and even a touch of alcohol coming through in the aroma; slightly scattered, candied nose.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: chewy caramel, dried red fruits, candy sugar, and some alcoholic edges showing through; reasonably tasty, but Id love to taste this next to the original, better(?) versions of this beer.  Still, tasty stuff.  Medium finish: sticky red fruits, candy sugar, caramel / nougat, and just a touch of mineral bitterness.

Courtesy of kmweaver. Clear dark amber body with a medium sized tan head. Rich toffee and dark fruit in the nose with some toast and berries. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. Im getting lots of fruit juice, especially grapes, figs and berries, there is also an abundance of caramel and cookie dough. Medium/full body is very soft with light and gentle carbonation.

Bottle from puzzl I think. Tried from bottle with Atlanta ratebeer crew at 5 Seasons North tasting. Red amber color.  Some roasty aroma.  Mild flavor.  A hint of sour and dry.  I was told this wasnt the best of batches, other batches are better.

Appearance: clear dark amber, wispy beige head, bits of lace, 
Aroma: sweet dark caramel aroma with an earthy peat character, 
Flavor: rich dark caramel flavor, touch of candy, nice balancing earthyness, light bitter finish,

Pours a deep amber color with a tan head.  Aroma is malty, toasty, peat, caramel, and earthy hops.  Flavor is malt, toasty, peat, roast, caramel, and a bitter peat earthy finish.

Appearance: Pours a clear, ruby red body with a small, bubbly, white head.

Smell: A peaty aroma with a slight nuttiness and notes of caramelized sugars, grain husks, and stewed fruits.

Taste: Grainy, dry malt taste with the sweetness of caramelized sugar and an underlying peat character. Hint of nuts. Juicy plum fruitiness. More grains. A pop of balancing hop bitterness. A continuing graininess overlooks the peaty, drying finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: A decent, well-made scotch ale.
12oz twist-off bottle.  Deep brown color.  Aroma of toasted malt, deep rich malts.  Flavor is a geat malt character, balanced with a very nice hop bitterness.  Not much smoke.Still very good.

341 mL bottle received via trade with Glouglouburp.  Pours clear brown with an average, fizzy, dark brown head, somewhat lasting with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (caramel, bread, cookie), light hops (grass), average yeast (dough) with notes of dates and cardboard.  Medium bodied, thin texture, average carbonation, and a bitter finish.  Long duration, moderate sweetness, light acidity and bitterness.

Poured a clear red-copper color with an a small off-white head.  Very malty with sweet toffee.  The malt seems to have an off aged character to it.  Earthy notes follow the malt to the nose.  The flavor is sweet and malty with a mild bitterness and semi-dry finish.  Medium-full bodied.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 Bottle, courtesy blankboy. Pours a dark amber red, with a watery ring of white head and very little lacing. Caramel up front in the nose, followed by some hops and molasses. First thing that hits the tongue is chalk, with caramel, and some sweet molasses. Tangy medicinal finish. Sharp flavors create stinging bitterness, and alcohol is hidden relatively well. Labeled as a scotch ale, feels more like an Arrogant Bastard homebrew clone.

(Dégusté avec french tickler) Bière rouge-vin (Style ruby) avec un tres beau collet collant. Odeur fumée, banane, senteur crémeuse, bois, caramel, barbe à papa. Un gout salé et poivré en meme temps, tres crémeuse, et un arriere gout fromager. Excellente biere!!

Shared with Pyrozoid.  Dark ruby red poor with a noce foamy light brown head.  Aromas of hickory, bananas, woody, nutty and creamy caramel. Very creamy, alcohol induced, full bodied, extremely well rounded brew.  Bitterness is extremely long  lasting and its sweetness hits you right off the bat.  Flavors are roaming around the alcohol... always very present.... but non-agressive...  This beer is simply amazing... ive been waiting for it for a while... i love it!

341 ml bottle from HogtownHarry; Bottle says 9%ABV; Nose was lagery grain and brown sugar when cold changing to toffee, brown sugary sweetness, and light smoky and hoppy notes; clear red-brown with a medium, glass-lacing, off-white head; flavor has light hop bitterness in the background, some yeastiness, and molasses and dark fruit notes; very different combo of flavors.

This was the first bottled batch, shared by iowaherkeye.  Copper color, tan head, good lacing, retention was OK.  Aroma was predominantly of malted milk balls, maybe a little bread coming through.  Taste was malted milk balls, sweet caramel, brown sugar, and some sherry.  Medium carbonation and body.  Decent, but I wouldnt go nuts trying to obtain.

Original batch 500ml bottle provided by Glouglouburp. Ive never had this fresh, but it seems to have lost a bit in these years in the bottle, which sucks, because I was seeking this out forever. Aroma is a bit milky, lactic, cardboardy weathered malts. Flavor is a bit more redeeming, with a gentle sweetness and calm malt characters that hints of something that used to be fantastic. Oxidation has taken over, though; a bit of sherry, but more cardboard, and a thin body. I do have a fresh bottle as well, although I hear its not as good; Ill certainly be rating that one sooner rather than later, and hopefully will be able to enjoy this beer as it was meant to be had.

500ml, thanks to after4ever! Pours translucent, and very dark brown with ruby highlights and a massive, lacy tan head. Big sweet aroma of brown sugar, smoke, molasses and nuts. Medium body and light carbonation. That same smoky, nutty molasses nose translates directly to the taste, with all sorts of little flavor swirls to compliment the main theme. I need to figure out how to brew this stuff.

500. Batch 1. Cant thank you enough, Glouglouburp! Holy cow, what an amazing beer. Pours crystal clear super dark brown with brilliant rubied highlights. Enormous sudsy tan head. Huge malty, bready nose--smells like biscuit, brown bread, and sweet caramel. Medium body, perfectly balanced: drinkable but complex, slows you down just enough to enjoy the pleasures of the flavor. Biscuit, brown tea, brown bread, caramel, nuts, and toast on the mid-palate. Peat showing through as well, mildly. Long tea finish. Mild herbal hop there at the end. Good stuff.

341ml bottle, dated Nov. 2007.

Pours perfectly clear cherry mahogany.
A beige head of medium to thick density built to a inch-plus, before settling into some remaining errant whisps on the surface. 
A few threads and ropes of lacework stuck around for the duration.
Aromatics are laced with bright and clean malt. Loads of malt and scorched kettle.
An alcohol presense makes itself known as well as a hint of smoke.
The mouthfeel is crisp, creamy, and sticky. Residuals stay tacked to the tongue.
The pallet is malt-forward, to say the least.
Loads of ripe barley, caramel, and a whiskey- like alcohol note.
Bitterness is subdued, as is all other hopping.
This brew is all about clean malt character and substantial strength.
Finishes with lingering malt, warming alcohol, and a hint of smoldered barley.

I was told that this brewery makes thier own barley, but the label has plenty of cryptic french, so I cannot confirm.
I was ready to be let down by this obscure small bottle that cost $6.99 in Quebec, but wowza! 
Probably the best Scotch ale Ive ever had.

Word.

Bottle, thanks for sharing iowaherkeye. The body was dark brown with a khaki head. The aroma was definite Whoppers. I got that from badbeer. There was also some pears and vanilla. The taste had Whoppers with some smoked malt. There was also some caramel. An overall light body with low carbonation. Well made.

12 oz. bottle shared by tjthresh.  Pour is brown, with slight ruby highlights.  Clear, with some carbonation and a 1/2 inch dirty white head.  Aroma is scotchy, nutty, with some faint woodiness.  Taste is thinner than I had expected, though the Scotch taste and woodiness come through nicely.  The finish has a slightly unpleasant soapy/cardboard thing going on.  Nice beer, thanks for sharing Tom.

12 ounce bottle from the Festivus guy.  Pours brown with thick brown head and good lace.  All malt here. A touch of peat maybe.  Woody.  Not the same thing as say Alesmith Wee Heavy.  They seem to be of two different styles.  Comes off like diluted Scotch Whiskey.  Light body.  Medium carbonation.  Dry finish.  Decent.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2008 Bouteille brune de 331 ml. Nez dalcool et de malt caramélisé. Robe cuivrée. Goût marqué par le malt caramélisé et lalcool. Une certaine amertume de houblon est présente en arrière-goût. Il sagit dune très bonne bière, mais le prix demandé nest peut-être pas totalement justifié.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2010 bouteille brune  de 341ml au prix exorbitant de 6,99$

nouvelle étiquette

bière qui a une belle robe rouge brique foncée, nez fruité un peu sucré, bouche alcooleuse, piquante, agressante. la longueur y est. manque déquilibre.trop forte.

Nouvelle tentative, malgré le prix, de loin supérieur, bon goût, belle longueur, bon malt caramel.

Bottle @ TimEs House: Dark mahogany color with a nice light head and plenty of lacing. The nose is sweet and caramelly with a nice licorice and plum note, some brown sugar, molasses and jaggery. The flavor is balanced, nice complex intense malts and a full body, nice tail and a full creamy mouthfeel.

Bottled. A deep red beer going towards light brown with an orange head. The aroma is sweet malty with strong notes of caramel and straw. The flavor is sweet with notes of caramel and wood, leading to a dry finish. Thanks to David (Rastacouere).

Bottle at LCRBM3.  Clear chestnut colour with lasting deep beige head.  Attractive dry malt aroma, bit of spicy raisin.  Thick in mouth.  It has a salt and vinegar aroma.  Its ok, a bit intense and thick.

A Mes rate: 
Bottle at LCRBM3. Deep dark amber colour with a slight off white head. Heavy malt aroma, very sweet and slightly roasty. This bottle was just starting to show some age. Flavour follows on well from the nose with heavy fruity complexity and a high level of sweetness that is almost too much but the roasted malt keeps it all under control especially once working in conjunction with the slight bitterness in the finish. Damn good balance. Lovely mouthfeel. Very good beer.

3rd LCRBM. Wood, apricot and raisin in the aroma. Sweet flavor with brown sugar. Grapefruit, raisin and apricot. Quite a complex beer! Just a hint of raisin in the aftertaste.

Small yellow head, deep red-amber beer. Alcohol, fusels, roasted aromas, dried fruit on straw. Caramel flavour, hand-made toffees, butterscotch but no diacetyl, autumn leaves, sweet and fruity esters. Sticky, alcohol in the palate. Excellent, even when sample slightly aged.
